ygData.subject: Re: Hell level?
ygData.msgSnippet: I m not sure anyone knows where proc comes from other than that Verant has used it to describe weapons and items that cast spells.  My guess would be that it
ygData.messageBody:
I'm not sure anyone knows where proc comes from other than that Verant has
used it to describe weapons and items that cast spells. My guess would be
that it refers to Pro C, that when a weapon casts a spell it triggers a Pro
C routine to do that, hence proc. Just a guess, could be way off base.

Or it could refer to the master enchanter Proc'Daron of S. Ro who is said to
have ivented the embedding spell that allows inanimate objects to cast
spells randomly, hence Proc. I hear the dervishes of that area actually
prefer the term Daron.

Kitasi of E'ci

-----Original Message-----
From: Bob Stewart [mailto:bstewart@...]
Sent: Monday, June 28, 1999 8:57 AM
To: eqbards@onelist.com
Subject: Re: [eqbards] Hell level?


From: Bob Stewart <bstewart@...>

At 01:34 AM 6/28/99 -0700, jay schultze wrote:
>Of course I couldn't wait to try out the proc on the Staff of Writhing -

What is "proc?" Where does the word come from? Words from inside the
software and its design, like "mob" have a way of slipping into the game.
Bet you haven't guessed that bothers me. :-)}

At least I have a good reason here. Programmers jargon is handy for
programmers but it leads to less understanding for those who are not.
Verant has a bad habit of using such jargon, even in system warnings, with
no explanation whatsoever of what it means.

It's unreasonable and inconsiderate to invent words or give old words new
meaning then expect others to know what they mean.

I've been fighting this battle in the software industry for 30 years. The
only real way to stem the tide of ugly jargon is to push back and refuse to
use it yourself, both of which I try to do.

Bob
